Jeff Langr wrote:

> 
> I'd also have to agree that the TestNG style is more elegant. The
> JUnit form is more idiomatic, so the first time a programmer sees it,
> it requires explanation. If you've been using TestNG (and thus are
> comfortable with annotations in the first place),
> @Test(expected=XException.class) is pretty obvious.

You guys all seem to forget this version:

     assertThrows(exception, closure);

Although it introduces an anonymous implementation of an interface, it 
has the added benefit of being able to assert that the closure throws an 
/instance/ of the exception, rather than simply the right type. This way 
I can check the exception data for correctness. I imagine it's easy to 
turn this into an annotation, if people prefer to program in two 
languages, rather than one.

Take care.
